stem: A client is 5 days post-Anterior MI with a large area of 'wall motion abnormality' (hypokinesis). Based on the documentation in the Post-MI Thrombotic & Perfusion Log, which finding indicates the most likely complication?

tabs.title: Clinical Status History
tabs.content:
Post-Op Day 1-4: Stable heart rate (70s), sinus rhythm. Client ambulating in room.
Day 5 (0800): Sudden onset of right-sided facial droop and right-arm weakness. Aphasia (inability to speak) noted.

tabs.title: Echocardiogram (admission)
tabs.content: LVEF: 25%. Finding: Large akinesis of the apex. Presence of a **mural thrombus** (clot attached to the heart wall) noted in the left ventricle.

tabs.title: Vital Signs & Neuro (0815)
tabs.content: BP 168/94, HR 82, SpO2 96%. NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) Score: 18 (Severe).

options.text: Embolic Stroke from a ventricular mural thrombus

rationale.correct: This is an **Embolic Stroke (a1)** originating from a **mural thrombus**. After a large MI, the heart muscle stops moving effectively (akinesis/hypokinesis). Stagnant blood in the left ventricle begins to clot against the wall (forming a 'mural' thrombus). If a piece of this clot breaks off, it goes directly to the brain (a1) or the limbs. The echo finding of an LV thrombus combined with the sudden facial droop and and aphasia is definitive for an embolic event.
clinicalPearls: Mural Thrombus = Clot on the 'Wall' of the heart.
Patients with LVEF < 30% or large anterior MIs often need anticoagulation (Warfarin) for 3-6 months to prevent this.
Priority: Stat CT Head and neurology consult.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Hemorrhagic Stroke (a2) because the patient is on blood thinners.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While possible, the **known presence of an LV mural thrombus** on the echo report makes an embolic (clot) cause significantly more likely in clinical reasoning. Always follow the 'known' anatomical risk.

mnemonic.title: Wall to Brain
mnemonic.expansion: Stagnant heart. Mural start. Breaks apart. Stroke at the chart.
